document.title: CollegeBoard AP US History Course Description

88CE55F7049D4440964F65854BFF06EA.description: This theme focuses on how and why systems of social organization develop and change as well as the impact that these systems have on the broader society.

B8F366C9081C4242BC84ED1310D3DE96.description: This theme focuses on the how and why national, regional, and group cultures developed and changed as well as how culture has shaped government policy and the economy.

CE640EC5EF454363AB02D316E29AB9E4.description: This theme focuses on the interactions between nations that affected North American history in the colonial period and on the influence of the United States on world affairs.

51B6C83ECC594B45951F3DE79A66794B.description: This theme focuses on how different social and political groups have influenced society and government in the United States as well as how political beliefs and institutions have changed over time.

116F2EFF991A40269E23C66DA4637F1D.description: This theme focuses on why and how the various people who moved to and within the United States both adapted to and transformed their new social and physical environments.

93CA9ECDF9D94656AD555D56DE6F4FE9.description: This theme focuses on the role of geography and both the natural and human-made environments in the social and political developments in what would become the United States.

BB2BB1804E0C4050BAAEC584C7FD30FC.description: This theme focuses on the factors behind the development of systems of economic exchange, particularly the role of technology, economic markets, and government.

442EF8F384274CDFA3B9A3B8C466BCCB.description: This theme focuses on how and why definitions of American and national identity and values have developed among the diverse and changing population of North America as well as on related topics, such as citizenship, constitutionalism, foreign policy, assimilation, and American exceptionalism.

7F3C2210A66A47C49FBFA31AEBFC8821.description: Explain the relative historical significance of specific historical developments in relation to a larger pattern of continuity and/or change.

F70BFD9CFE7441BEB36E25BB62E2816F.description: Explain patterns of continuity and/or change over time.

428C219AE1D44ABD9DBE08E5B6EB840B.description: Describe patterns of continuity and/or change over time.

04FE703B5C654972AA92C72062BE5446.description: Explain the relative historical significance of different causes and/or effects.

A1350A245BC745ABA7F9FFD253B87650.description: Explain how a relevant context influenced a specific historical development or process.

408CD6EEBBE64C72817610763FEE5302.description: Explain the difference between primary and secondary causes and between short- and long-term effects.

B65F0669138D4E38A26A830841F14FDC.description: Explain the relationship between causes and effects of a specific historical development or process.

65E74F047A17410C85B50005A22A859B.description: Describe causes and/or effects of a specific historical development or process.

856C85D6A1604814B7B4699814472386.description: Explain the relative historical significance of similarities and/or differences between different historical developments or processes.

1179D03539254BBCA15995EEB6D5D173.description: Explain relevant similarities and/or differences between specific historical developments and processes.

0060B9C8F682402AA770AD9A612B9190.description: Describe similarities and/or differences between different historical developments and processes.

80628EA722804F12A0AD142C8EEE92C1.description: Explain how or why a historical claim or argument is or is not effective.

BC56155D8BAC48F1A7AA073600CA44D7.description: Explain the relative historical significance of a source’s credibility and limitations.

CF2AE2AB10D14B38A0385AF744CA998F.description: Explain relevant and insightful connections within and across time periods.

FE8E89378B0E40389D17530BEC8512DD.description: Explain nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables.

BF68851674EA43E5B4892CDECB6FB3A0.description: Corroborate, qualify, or modify an argument using diverse and alternative evidence in order to develop a complex argument.  This argument might:

EA71096E9B5742519548034E3BD39518.description: Use historical reasoning to explain relationships among pieces of historical evidence.

1AF2D00B3EAC421DAE2315858E674394.description: Explain how specific examples of historically relevant evidence support an argument.

76AF401062BE4035B5ED7CC1BA5B1516.description: Describe specific examples of historically relevant evidence.

FD572B1B4B314986AD1B415E77C67BC5.description: Support an argument using specific and relevant evidence.

15B20E83B10F4015884F60E4705DCA77.description: Explain how a historical development or process relates to another historical development or process.

112E72CF6A9B43FB92E170FCA19DE3F7.description: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.

0C98301F5A8C4E97BB11C1790B482D10.description: Explain how a specific historical development or process is situated within a broader historical context.

0E69D61C78CD4DA8B8F745757F19C6FC.description: Identify and describe a historical context for a specific historical development or process.

87161C2E681848528277A6CDA9A40869.description: Explain how claims or evidence support, modify, or refute a source’s argument.

7BF83561083D4C2F85D81C714B9A9DC3.description: Compare the arguments or main ideas of two sources.

5DFF459E55654E019EBC6677EFB239B3.description: Identify the evidence used in a source to support an argument.

8931C9859AA44C3A80C0C760905C81DF.description: Identify and describe a claim and/or argument in a text-based or non-text-based source.

03F09CCF05FC4BB9A046C5B1081CD361.description: Explain the significance of a source’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience, including how these might limit the use(s) of a source.

C372F210AB99445885FC370DBD3A9242.description: Explain the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of a source.

37A9E89CB9C34114946DB2A7BC0CCF33.description: Identify a source’s point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience.

6A8ADA678F9C4A22B8BFBE5A3E374698.description: Explain a historical concept, development, or process.

16C2C5AC89C54A3A975329B711AD8B8D.description: Identify a historical concept, development, or process.

087B683FBB6747849C67FB984CF3ADCA.description: Despite economic and foreign policy challenges, the United States continued as the world’s leading superpower in the 21st century.

D1B0940A79A24B73B8E5902344F1C766.description: Conflicts in the Middle East and concerns about climate change led to debates over U.S. dependence on fossil fuels and the impact of economic consumption on the environment.

B478475734A94935A978787DF3316D4E.description: The war on terrorism sought to improve security within the United States but also raised questions about the protection of civil liberties and human rights.

923D5266BB2D4E7EBFB209859DCB9704.description: In the wake of attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon, the United States launched military efforts against terrorism and lengthy, controversial conflicts in Afghanistan and Iraq.

399EEC7BA88F409795F9B8A2C121B7B2.description: Following the attacks of September 11, 2001, U.S. foreign policy efforts focused on fighting terrorism around the world.

6F1AF82656194E4592BF06B718599FA8.description: The end of the Cold War led to new diplomatic relationships but also new U.S. military and peacekeeping interventions, as well as continued debates over the appropriate use of American power in the world.

84541C4C2CCA487084BB95F4801EE872.description: Increased U.S. military spending, Reagan’s diplomatic initiatives, and political changes and economic problems in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union were all important in ending the Cold War.

F4F1081094BA431A8CDF81C4030F01FB.description: Reagan asserted U.S. opposition to communism through speeches, diplomatic efforts, limited military interventions, and a buildup of nuclear and conventional weapons.

29395D1057E44790A97D8EC0CE1037D6.description: The Reagan administration promoted an interventionist foreign policy that continued in later administrations, even after the end of the Cold War.

17A28D26399243CA9C9A54DD1BD153EC.description: The end of the Cold War and new challenges to U.S. leadership forced the nation to redefine its foreign policy and role in the world.

3C1354B51A264A0CA6E1A0422E8D8D6C.description: Intense political and cultural debates continued over issues such as immigration policy, diversity, gender roles, and family structure.

9BFA7B1504374D8EB1B21C9F0B8C0724.description: International migration from Latin America and Asia increased dramatically.  The new immigrants affected U.S. culture in many ways and supplied the economy with an important labor force.

D3484067471648BC835982BF974445DF.description: After 1980, the political, economic, and cultural influence of the American South and West continued to increase as population shifted to those areas.

F9D035896BBF47B6A50D023AE22AD692.description: The U.S. population continued to undergo demographic shifts that had significant cultural and political consequences.

64076FA70DDF49EAADBAAD84D28472A8.description: Real wages stagnated for the working and middle class amid growing economic inequality.

BBDD0CDD25CC4B3E9A8065998D6B0F4A.description: Employment increased in service sectors and decreased in manufacturing, and union membership declined.

088FEA0364F14ED1AED39AA5D0A48E46.description: Technological innovations in computing, digital mobile technology, and the Internet transformed daily life, increased access to information, and led to new social behaviors and networks.

778C17483D9344519245569695C062B4.description: Economic productivity increased as improvements in digital communications enabled increased American participation in worldwide economic opportunities.

DC142210C05F4A60BF83F0D117AA3F1C.description: New developments in science and technology enhanced the economy and transformed society, while manufacturing decreased.

D63E120CDADD4F11954B515306F4CCE8.description: Moving into the 21st century, the nation experienced significant technological, economic, and demographic changes.

A4F5BFCCF56C40D3AD1A86E40F0A4886.description: Policy debates continued over free-trade agreements, the scope of the government social safety net, and calls to reform the U.S. financial system.

6B47BBEC39D2437C81048BF93159D4A7.description: Conservatives argued that liberal programs were counterproductive in fighting poverty and stimulating economic growth.  Some of their efforts to reduce the size and scope of government met with inertia and liberal opposition, as many programs remained popular with voters.

9D11E34D965946FA8E8AE3324243B8DF.description: Ronald Reagan’s victory in the presidential election of 1980 represented an important milestone, allowing conservatives to enact significant tax cuts and continue deregulation of many industries.

4F72D5F8667C47A8AF8FF1DF1EE689FE.description: Conservative beliefs regarding the need for traditional social values and a reduced role for government advanced in U.S. politics after 1980.

E023569166FC40D394AE5850B2861656.description: A new ascendant conservative movement achieved several political and policy goals during the 1980s and continued to strongly influence public discourse in the following decades.

20CC360AEE8E490886B4172029C8CD89.description: The rapid and substantial growth of evangelical Christian churches and organizations was accompanied by greater political and social activism on the part of religious conservatives.

FC043C1CDB514D1485C7D561C8AAE0C9.description: Feminists and young people who participated in the counterculture of the 1960s rejected many of the social, economic, and political values of their parents’ generation, introduced greater informality into U.S. culture, and advocated changes in sexual norms.

DF3A2720EE8E4096BD57FEF885C1E338.description: Mass culture became increasingly homogeneous in the postwar years, inspiring challenges to conformity by artists, intellectuals, and rebellious youth.

445ED69F87DA4BC7B9E09B2CEE9B9FC2.description: New demographic and social developments, along with anxieties over the Cold War, changed U.S. culture and led to significant political and moral debates that sharply divided the nation.

6D1B2E6222B74350AC0AE987C60E8AEB.description: Immigrants from around the world sought access to the political, social, and economic opportunities in the United States, especially after the passage of new immigration laws in 1965.

6E70294A8C414925AD545FE29A230771.description: As higher education opportunities and new technologies rapidly expanded, increasing social mobility encouraged the migration of the middle class to the suburbs and of many Americans to the South and West.  The Sun Belt region emerged as a significant political and economic force.

FA392FE068E24D6F8A3A57117BB5AEBE.description: A burgeoning private sector, federal spending, the baby boom, and technological developments helped spur economic growth.

6C0F6102DC3D4B9DB6A6A3F84659E0D0.description: Rapid economic and social changes in American society fostered a sense of optimism in the postwar years.

B222D135FCD845179FF56A5D2CFB9E48.description: Postwar economic and demographic changes had far-reaching consequences for American society, politics, and culture.

9E55BAC349BD4031A063FC8C65E6DFBB.description: The 1970s saw growing clashes between conservatives and liberals over social and cultural issues, the power of the federal government, race, and movements for greater individual rights.

3181B88B62FD4A4EB55EA4A574591420.description: Public confidence and trust in government’s ability to solve social and economic problems declined in the 1970s in the wake of economic challenges, political scandals, and foreign policy crises.

574D320A65BE4E1C96258FDDFE7FE8A5.description: Some groups on the left also rejected liberal policies, arguing that political leaders did too little to transform the racial and economic status quo at home and pursued immoral policies abroad.

EEE302E342804034B3AABE298AD494B2.description: In the 1960s, conservatives challenged liberal laws and court decisions and perceived moral and cultural decline, seeking to limit the role of the federal government and enact more assertive foreign policies.

A8C7569A307942CB96DF45BF52148C0F.description: Liberal ideas found expression in Lyndon Johnson’s Great Society, which attempted to use federal legislation and programs to end racial discrimination, eliminate poverty, and address other social issues.  A series of Supreme Court decisions expanded civil rights and individual liberties.

AF444A569A1243C4B4F97426CE64FEE4.description: Liberalism, based on anticommunism abroad and a firm belief in the efficacy of government power to achieve social goals at home, reached a high point of political influence by the mid-1960s.

F6D3829D761A4446A64137854C0D6162.description: Liberalism influenced postwar politics and court decisions, but it came under increasing attack from the left as well as from a resurgent conservative movement.

84D3D7451DE441279D0AED2D8A262501.description: Environmental problems and accidents led to a growing environmental movement that aimed to use legislative and public efforts to combat pollution and protect natural resources.  The federal government established new environmental programs and regulations.

CD1E2089E9BE4F4C9B0EE86C60089ED6.description: Despite an overall affluence in postwar America, advocates raised concerns about the prevalence and persistence of poverty as a national problem.

A40258FA94EA4A3F873D2B04A4F2A7A8.description: Latino, American Indian, and Asian American movements continued to demand social and economic equality and a redress of past injustices.

34825CF5086C41DEACAD796DF1BBBC09.description: Feminist and gay and lesbian activists mobilized behind claims for legal, economic, and social equality.

DD782C2CBE0A4E48909389D960AB1A5E.description: Responding to social conditions and the African American civil rights movement, a variety of movements emerged that focused on issues of identity, social justice, and the environment.

810B76E7960D4B53BEA7452AE48811DD.description: Continuing resistance slowed efforts at desegregation, sparking social and political unrest across the nation.  Debates among civil rights activists over the efficacy of nonviolence increased after 1965.

564D0C88A48B4CC2ADEA717E40D717FD.description: The three branches of government used measures including desegregation of the armed services, Brown v. Board of Education, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to promote greater racial equality.

BA94D565D2D74A6CBAF154C208175CA3.description: During and after World War II, civil rights activists and leaders, most notably Martin Luther King Jr., combatted racial discrimination utilizing a variety of strategies, including legal challenges, direct action, and nonviolent protest tactics.

EA676E0160624BDE82AA94A8E8631560.description: Seeking to fulfill Reconstruction-era promises, civil rights activists and political leaders achieved some legal and political successes in ending segregation, although progress toward racial equality was slow.

D27D5DBA5CFE4A4EB51A0EC2EC4A879B.description: New movements for civil rights and liberal efforts to expand the role of government generated a range of political and cultural responses.

53D49F170EEF4FA0AD46AA6B8195DB49.description: Ideological, military, and economic concerns shaped U.S. involvement in the Middle East, with several oil crises in the region eventually sparking attempts at creating a national energy policy.

EE9E1E4EA86C4FABB6D77A9547045111.description: Americans debated the merits of a large nuclear arsenal, the military-industrial complex, and the appropriate power of the executive branch in conducting foreign and military policy.

2E8FCACB24D64F169395ECEFA338CD94.description: Although anticommunist foreign policy faced little domestic opposition in previous years, the Vietnam War inspired sizable and passionate antiwar protests that became more numerous as the war escalated and sometimes led to violence.

38AB74AED07B41AE87245B3EFBFD6291.description: Americans debated policies and methods designed to expose suspected communists within the United States even as both parties supported the broader strategy of containing communism.

543BE7C83A7B47D5882451CDBA8C4273.description: Cold War policies led to public debates over the power of the federal government and acceptable means of pursuing international and domestic goals while protecting civil liberties.

87732C159DCF45F2AF4664963BB25EBF.description: Cold War competition extended to Latin America, where the U.S. supported non-Communist regimes that had varying levels of commitment to democracy.

107DC7DDEF3E40FFB632D26505BD7FB5.description: Postwar decolonization and the emergence of powerful nationalist movements in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East led both sides in the Cold War to seek allies among new nations, many of which remained nonaligned.

F08DAE19F02C42FE8C3B21C17244DB09.description: The Cold War fluctuated between periods of direct and indirect military confrontation and periods of mutual coexistence (or détente).

B7D43344741E48E589C592A02ED50547.description: Concerned by expansionist Communist ideology and Soviet repression, the United States sought to contain communism through a variety of measures, including major military engagements in Korea and Vietnam.

52D5296B81124AD7B374E504AFB9238F.description: As postwar tensions dissolved the wartime alliance between Western democracies and the Soviet Union, seeking to limit the growth of Communist military power and ideological influence, create a free-market global economy, and build an international security system.

6AF5070F6FBA4214BD35A0748518B379.description: United States policymakers engaged in a cold war with the authoritarian Soviet Union, seeking to limit the growth of Communist military power and ideological influence, create a free-market global economy, and build an international security system.

F06908D67CB74596B51000BC7785E74A.description: The United States responded to an uncertain and unstable postwar world by asserting and working to maintain a position of global leadership, with far-reaching domestic and international consequences.

0F32896316B74EB7A60898D4A480156C.description: The war-ravaged condition of Asia and Europe, and the dominant U.S. role in the Allied victory and postwar peace settlements, allowed the United States to emerge from the war as the most powerful nation on earth.

A77D155183DD47A9886351E751DBE300.description: The United States and its allies achieved military victory through Allied cooperation, technological and scientific advances, the contributions of servicemen and women, and campaigns such as Pacific “island-hopping” and the D-Day invasion.  The use of atomic bombs hastened the end of the war and sparked debates about the morality of using atomic weapons.

93D0884CA92D48F0AD614789B06C0BBC.description: Mobilization and military service provided opportunities for women and minorities to improve their socioeconomic positions for the war’s duration, while also leading to debates over racial segregation.  Wartime experiences also generated challenges to civil liberties, such as the internment of Japanese Americans.

585E6A23332D48E3A143AB70C8002150.description: The mass mobilization of American society helped end the Great Depression, and the country’s strong industrial base played a pivotal role in winning the war by equipping and provisioning allies and millions of U.S. troops.

4DB5CD61F14D441BA20906741D181CF3.description: Americans viewed the war as a fight for the survival of freedom and democracy against fascist and militarist ideologies.  This perspective was later reinforced by revelations about Japanese wartime atrocities, Nazi concentration camps, and the Holocaust.

8FD973049A1345A9B8BA56E7562090D2.description: U.S. participation in World War II transformed American society, while the victory of the United States and its allies over the Axis powers vaulted the U.S. into a position of global, political, and military leadership.

E00CC9CA996442F6B1CA17C39E42B7C9.description: In the 1930s, while many Americans were concerned about the rise of fascism and totalitarianism, most opposed taking military action against the aggression of Nazi Germany and Japan until the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor drew the United States into World War II.

96D3D35F093849928C1862DA7F9B5822.description: In the years following World War I, the United States pursued a unilateral foreign policy that used international investment, peace treaties, and select military intervention to promote a vision of international order, even while maintaining U.S. isolationism.

D648647C275F49B1979C679B13EA14EB.description: Despite Wilson’s deep involvement in postwar negotiations, the U.S. Senate refused to ratify the Treaty of Versailles or join the League of Nations.

ACA7E7C75624455FBEBD8A0A588A5346.description: Although the American Expeditionary Forces played a relatively limited role in combat, the U.S.’s entry helped to tip the balance of the conflict in favor of the Allies.

11D4DB609A244755A8329BDB4CFB0694.description: After initial neutrality in World War I, the nation entered the conflict, departing from the U.S. foreign policy tradition of noninvolvement in European affairs, in response to Woodrow Wilson’s call for the defense of humanitarian and democratic principles.

B57C82E23E884733A2FF8F372F54071A.description: World War I and its aftermath intensified ongoing debates about the nation’s role in the world and how best to achieve national security and pursue American interests.

216EB5ECABC246F2A6BECA9075ED94CF.description: The American victory in the Spanish-American War led to the U.S. acquisition of island territories in the Caribbean and the Pacific, an increase in involvement in Asia, and the suppression of a nationalist movement in the Philippines.

9F1C9CDA1A194D1F91AB81DBC5D4A043.description: Anti-imperialists cited principles of self-determination and invoked both racial theories and the U.S. foreign policy tradition of isolationism to argue that the U.S. should not extend its territory overseas.

BFA2D41DC9B04F6D873A8C99C92A63A2.description: Imperialists cited economic opportunities, racial theories, competition with European empires, and the perception in the 1890s that the western frontier was “closed” to argue that Americans were destined to expand their culture and institutions to peoples around the globe.

98E4702317DA47D8BC0DE111EA350C84.description: In the late 19th century and early 20th century, new U.S. territorial ambitions and acquisitions in the Western Hemisphere and the Pacific accompanied heightened public debates over America’s role in the world.

2F4DDC53A6574C20B53CC0C1B6E16658.description: Participation in a series of global conflicts propelled the United States into a position of international power while renewing domestic debates over the nation’s proper role in the world.

EC4F672B2663490DB05DCD99F065FF20.description: Migration to the United States from Mexico and elsewhere in the Western Hemisphere increased, in spite of contradictory government policies toward Mexican immigration.

FF91519DD8044867B9D1F5DB55BA7C29.description: In a Great Migration during and after World War I, African Americans escaping segregation, racial violence, and limited economic opportunity in the South moved to the North and West, where they found new opportunities but still encountered discrimination.

3785209A83C74E0D97216AE0A110DF77.description: The increased demand for war production and labor during World War I and World War II and the economic difficulties of the 1930s led many Americans to migrate to urban centers in search of economic opportunities.

3FFD40EB697B40ADAF2DDB66FC57246B.description: Immigration from Europe reached its peak in the years before World War I.  During and after World War I, nativist campaigns against some ethnic groups led to the passage of quotas that restricted immigration, particularly from southern and eastern Europe, and increased barriers to Asian immigration.

D4E1B8690BF24FD28534355AF5B25200.description: Economic pressures, global events, and political developments caused sharp variations in the numbers, sources, and experiences of both international and internal migrants.

C2AF9CC393004A519B1E0C01491F646D.description: In the 1920s, cultural and political controversies emerged as Americans debated gender roles, modernism, science, religion, and issues related to race and immigration.

AD9575D937E54532A3BB80380655B39D.description: Official restrictions on freedom of speech grew during World War I, as increased anxiety about radicalism led to a Red Scare and attacks on labor activism and immigrant culture.

BAAA97041CB44248A08DE65A4D4CC22E.description: Migration gave rise to new forms of art and literature that expressed ethnic and regional identities, such as the Harlem Renaissance movement.

418BC82DD2A14F3290A662E0331C9B0D.description: New forms of mass media, such as radio and cinema, contributed to the spread of national culture as well as greater awareness of regional cultures.

40DD9217372745F8AA1FA1579B762795.description: Popular culture grew in influence in U.S. society, even as debates increased over the effects of culture on public values, morals, and American national identity.

AF60370E5B024671BAF79A13EB4ECF2A.description: Innovations in communications and technology contributed to the growth of mass culture, while significant changes occurred in internal and international migration patterns.

A4E57A57FBCB4981BD415EBCB6A58D48.description: Although the New Deal did not end the Depression, it left a legacy of reforms and regulatory agencies and fostered a long-term political realignment in which many ethnic groups, African Americans, and working-class communities identified with the Democratic Party.

86BA4A96224C4F86AE337764BD541352.description: Radical, union, and populist movements pushed Roosevelt toward more extensive efforts to change the American economic system, while conservatives in Congress and the Supreme Court sought to limit the New Deal’s scope.

0D486470DEC345CA85295379C9A0BE32.description: Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal attempted to end the Great Depression by using government power to provide relief to the poor, stimulate recovery, and reform the American economy.

1919FAA1B24541149B3A3BB7B1EC49A7.description: During the 1930s, policymakers responded to the mass unemployment and social upheavals of the Great Depression by transforming the U.S. into a limited welfare state, redefining the goals and ideas of modern American liberalism.

3FD317672F134AAC882F841C2816E6F2.description: The Progressives were divided over many issues.  Some Progressives supported Southern segregation, while others ignored its presence.  Some Progressives advocated expanding popular participation in government, while others called for greater reliance on professional and technical experts to make government more efficient.  Progressives also disagreed about immigration restriction.

2C7742389F7242E48C8130246CE35BC0.description: Preservationists and conservationists both supported the establishment of national parks while advocating different government responses to the overuse of natural resources.

E84D7E795535477BA1D361930B88174B.description: On the national level, Progressives sought federal legislation that they believed would effectively regulate the economy, expand democracy, and generate moral reform.  Progressive amendments to the Constitution dealt with issues such as prohibition and woman suffrage.

F91B03728F27402692A940EB6A56A14C.description: Some Progressive Era journalists attacked what they saw as political corruption, social injustice, and economic inequality, while reformers, often from the middle and upper classes and including many women, worked to effect social changes in cities and among immigrant populations.

58337187ED7D45F5B3410D512D9BDA7A.description: In the Progressive Era of the early 20th century, Progressives responded to political corruption, economic instability, and social concerns by calling for greater government action and other political and social measures.

F80690B1D012464BB809696802CA8777.description: Episodes of credit and market instability in the early 20th century, in particular the Great Depression, led to calls for a stronger financial regulatory system.

E4001AA01443439A9D3921401917D2B1.description: By 1920, a majority of the U.S. population lived in urban centers, which offered new economic opportunities for women, international migrants, and internal migrants.

2A19A5D49533421C9A4EC07A60C4FDDE.description: New technologies and manufacturing techniques helped focus the U.S. economy on the production of consumer goods, contributing to improved standards of living, greater personal mobility, and better communications systems.

202D7C9763964431842F75BCA20482C8.description: The United States continued its transition from a rural, agricultural economy to an urban, industrial economy led by large companies.

8CB8549C84914458B53A888C15947E15.description: Growth expanded opportunity, while economic instability led to new efforts to reform U.S. society and its economic system.

5269639A83FC46FAB57DF125E8140CD9.description: The Supreme Court decision in Plessy v. Ferguson that upheld racial segregation helped to mark the end of most of the political gains African Americans made during Reconstruction.  Facing increased violence, discrimination, and scientific theories of race, African American reformers continued to fight for political and social equality.

E6A25EF1202941FAA74B255E6BEB95B8.description: Many women sought greater equality with men, often joining voluntary organizations, going to college, promoting social and political reform, and, like Jane Adams, working in settlement houses to help immigrants adapt to U.S. language and customs.

E2EE053630D94AD2AB2E94F977336150.description: The major political parties appealed to lingering divisions from the Civil War and contended over tariffs and currency issues, even as reformers argued that economic greed and self-interest had corrupted all levels of government.

E43317BFA2764CD989D4BA33E5F74526.description: Dramatic social changes in the period inspired political debates over citizenship, corruption, and the proper relationship between business and government.

5F51B458F26F4EC2ACA592DD238922A5.description: A number of artists and critics, including agrarians, utopians, socialists, and advocates of the Social Gospel, championed alternative visions for the economy and U.S. society.

BAF4ECA929A945E2905F4E80C2C4D12C.description: Some business leaders argued that the wealthy had a moral obligation to help the less fortunate and improve society, as articulated in the idea known as the Gospel of Wealth, and they made philanthropic contributions that enhanced educational opportunities and urban environments.

73694729CD1B4AECA9C8048E564C3EC4.description: Social commentators advocated theories later described as Social Darwinism to justify the success of those at the top of the socioeconomic structure as both appropriate and inevitable.

5A66F33BD75747C4B35320175AE51374.description: New cultural and intellectual movements both buttressed and challenged the social order of the Gilded Age.

5B815CEC8D4348B1B1AA70C11F9A6CCF.description: The Gilded Age produced new cultural and intellectual movements, public reform efforts, and political debates over economic and social policies.

B544A0F6B92146F6A42F9447E2EA38F0.description: Many American Indians preserved their cultures and tribal identities despite government policies promoting assimilation, and they attempted to develop self-sustaining economic practices.

023C93DF749F4929AB0E347336F7EB64.description: The U.S. government violated treaties with American Indians and responded to resistance with military force, eventually confining American Indians to reservations and denying tribal sovereignty.

7431A39CEB104786B2E6F24F75D55083.description: As migrant populations increased in number and the American bison population was decimated, competition for land and resources in the West among white settlers, American Indians, and Mexican Americans led to an increase in violent conflict.

E8FE6BD301144F0A8C65F50DEDB9AD4C.description: In hopes of achieving ideals of self-sufficiency and independence, migrants moved both to rural and boomtown areas of the West for opportunities, such as building the railroads, mining, farming, and ranching.

7C7E11EEF1F24162A701C7FAF96B47AF.description: The building of transcontinental railroads, the discovery of mineral resources, and government policies promoted economic growth and created new communities and centers of commercial activity.

27917952858041FEA872D6C2D3C96585.description: Larger numbers of migrants moved to the West in search of land and economic opportunity, frequently provoking competition and violent conflict.

71AD5B04DC9B402B94F57D7C26C014B8.description: Corporations’ need for managers and for male and female clerical workers as well as increased access to educational institutions, fostered the growth of a distinctive middle class.  A growing amount of leisure time also helped expand consumer culture.

B47F595109724ACE84316C874C823751.description: In an urban atmosphere where the access to power was unequally distributed, political machines thrived, in part by providing immigrants and the poor with social services.

547F47D1105640019CAED9BDD1F0A5BE.description: Increasing public debates over assimilation and Americanization accompanied the growth of international migration.  Many immigrants negotiated compromises between the cultures they brought and the culture they found in the United States.

D10AC7A880694269ABABC7EA2602857E.description: Urban neighborhoods based on particular ethnicities, races, and classes provided new cultural opportunities for city dwellers.

B906F0410E2D477E983548943F2C3F58.description: As cities became areas of economic growth featuring new factories and businesses, they attracted immigrants from Asia and from southern and eastern Europe, as well as African American migrants within and out of the South.  Many migrants moved to escape poverty, religious persecution, and limited opportunities for social mobility in their home countries or regions.

BAB7CE3162F2497B92740EDC3CA94705.description: International and internal migration increased urban populations and fostered the growth of a new urban culture.

00411A55EF6C49EAB9770C66987DF84A.description: The migrations that accompanied industrialization transformed both urban and rural areas of the United States and caused dramatic social and cultural change.

A311B7CED7224B32A450E6048E629550.description: Economic instability inspired agrarian activists to create the People’s (Populist) Party, which called for a stronger governmental role in regulating the American economic system.

F443F66AA9324C849F5875CB13D0B36C.description: Many farmers responded to the increasing consolidation in agricultural markets and their dependence on the evolving railroad system by creating local and regional cooperative organizations.

46DBCB792957458EB54ADDFE250B0F3C.description: Improvements in mechanization helped agricultural production increase substantially and contributed to declines in food prices.

7BE7DAA7FD3C4839A8776A1B5EE82E2B.description: New systems of production and transportation enabled consolidation within agriculture, which, along with periods of instability, spurred a variety of responses from farmers.

587DEF1AC0E748C78632074A69DDDA0C.description: Despite the industrialization of some segments of the Southern economy—a change promoted by Southern leaders who called for a “New South”—agriculture based on sharecropping and tenant farming continued to be the primary economic activity in the South.

58FC8F3DF2354AF9B833BD073E07C7AD.description: Labor and management battled over wages and working conditions, with workers organizing local and national unions and/or directly confronting business leaders.

BFBE113AEC2A4DB5B1EE2C6D39CE3E0B.description: The industrial workforce expanded and became more diverse through internal and international migration; child labor also increased.

88A163DFC1C84EDE8DA8069D28F68C2F.description: Some argued that laissez-faire policies and competition promoted economic growth in the long run, and they opposed government intervention during economic downturns.

DEC6C059366C4B92B6E81E2925C6D581.description: A variety of perspectives on the economy and labor developed during a time of financial panics and downturns.

92687737603E457F90E304D1646F9D0F.description: Businesses and foreign policymakers increasingly looked outside U.S. borders in an effort to gain greater influence and control over markets and natural resources in the Pacific Rim, Asia, and Latin America.

ECFF2A20AEA449BE987A78B5F0CA6F08.description: Many business leaders sought increased profits by consolidating corporations into large trusts and holding companies, which further concentrated wealth.

7D8D4AEF7C8F44798C6A7B0F9AEA06C7.description: As the price of many goods decreased, workers’ real wages increased, providing new access to a variety of goods and services; many Americans’ standards of living improved, while the gap between the rich and poor grew.

58D10E92AF0A4EC598902DE029AC851A.description: Businesses made use of technological innovations, greater access to natural resources, redesigned financial and management structures, advances in marketing, and a growing labor force to dramatically increase the production of goods.

4EA3582A82D644B4945559C329870419.description: Following the Civil War, government subsidies for transportation and communication systems helped open new markets in North America.

D68B55A447E94A7794227EB5B39E6D3E.description: Large-scale industrial production—accompanied by massive technological change, expanding international communication networks, and pro-growth government policies—generated rapid economic development and business consolidation.

F9ABDD6AA9FC48B2A9EEE2315270F107.description: Technological advances, large-scale production methods, and the opening of new markets encouraged the rise of industrial capitalism in the United States.

F2BB2CB845FC4784A7C78BA7BF8EAD31.description: Segregation, violence, Supreme Court decisions, and local political tactics progressively stripped away African American rights, but the 14th and 15th amendments eventually became the basis for court decisions upholding civil rights in the 20th century.

77AA16BFBE124DDC9D8398257D1CF599.description: Southern plantation owners continued to own the majority of the region’s land even after Reconstruction.  Former slaves sought land ownership but generally fell short of self-sufficiency, as an exploitative and soil-intensive sharecropping system limited blacks’ and poor whites’ access to land in the South.

3EBDD5BB96F14B51B580B22AD53521BD.description: Efforts by radical and moderate Republicans to change the balance of power between Congress and the presidency and to reorder race relations in the defeated South yielded some short-term successes.  Reconstruction opened up political opportunities and other leadership roles to former slaves, but it ultimately failed, due both to determined Southern resistance and the North’s waning resolve.

92A62E3C97B84C508320F6DE305F09DA.description: The women’s rights movement was both emboldened and divided over the 14th and 15th amendments to the Constitution.

8721C4FF861A493CA8FA8AC08A2B7C81.description: The 13th Amendment abolished slavery, while the 14th and 15th amendments granted African Americans citizenship, equal protection under the laws, and voting rights.

85414F23923546D08D45FDD6EFAB6D20.description: Reconstruction and the Civil War ended slavery, altered relationships between the states and the federal government, and led to debates over new definitions of citizenship, particularly regarding the rights of African Americans, women, and other minorities.

E122851727654C238B9D22D50AE1147A.description: Although the Confederacy showed military initiative and daring early in the war, the Union ultimately succeeded due to improvements in leadership and strategy, key victories, greater resources, and the wartime destruction of the South’s infrastructure.

B0120651523348BBB8E26C60DFDB783F.description: Lincoln sought to reunify the country and used speeches such as the Gettysburg Address to portray the struggle against slavery as the fulfillment of America’s founding democratic ideals.

8C16E422A8B74E61812B8D8FF2D88FB8.description: Lincoln and most Union supporters began the Civil War to preserve the Union, but Lincoln’s decision to issue the Emancipation Proclamation reframed the purpose of the war and helped prevent the Confederacy from gaining full diplomatic support from European powers.  Many African Americans fled southern plantations and enlisted in the Union Army, helping to undermine the Confederacy.

BEC4E9D0EA0641D1B5382E1F186DD166.description: Both the Union and the Confederacy mobilized their economies and societies to wage the war even while facing considerable home front opposition.

64D7E68AD75140928CB3D596B892DD1A.description: The North’s greater manpower and industrial resources, the leadership of Abraham Lincoln and others, and the decision to emancipate slaves eventually led to the Union military victory over the Confederacy in the devastating Civil War.

6043E781982D4BEF8483DC7CCFE7A9DC.description: The Union victory in the Civil War and the contested reconstruction of the South settled the issues of slavery and secession, but left unresolved many questions about the power of the federal government and citizenship rights.

E71CDC2E26574A93A2390C1F140BB45E.description: Abraham Lincoln’s victory on the Republicans’ free-soil platform in the presidential election of 1860 was accomplished without any Southern electoral votes.  After a series of contested debates about secession, most slave states voted to secede from the Union, precipitating the Civil War.

71BEA7FB82D24697B41790443368851F.description: The Second Party System ended when the issues of slavery and anti-immigrant nativism weakened loyalties to the two major parties and fostered the emergence of sectional parties, most notably the Republican Party in the North.

31BC2D6846D4462096F064D5E757DF2E.description: The courts and national leaders made a variety of attempts to resolve the issue of slavery in the territories, including the Compromise of 1850, the Kansas-Nebraska Act, and the Dred Scott decision, but these ultimately failed to reduce conflict.

ACA378E7D00B45E6A6C07B5533BCB385.description: The Mexican Cession led to heated controversies over whether to allow slavery in the newly acquired territories.

7944A712C95A4650A2F9DCFFC88202E6.description: Debates over slavery came to dominate political discussion in the 1850s, culminating in the bitter election of 1860 and the secession of Southern states.

AC631CD888004BBFBAD7BD11F032ADE3.description: Defenders of slavery based their arguments on racial doctrines, the view that slavery was a positive social good, and the belief that slavery and states’ rights were protected by the Constitution.

78BFED951F0D4A62B023A5BCDB933EB0.description: African American and white abolitionists, although a minority in the North, mounted a highly visible campaign against slavery, presenting moral arguments against the institution, assisting slaves’ escapes, and sometimes expressing a willingness to use violence to achieve their goals.

F345819D46374BCE8F0AA810C16D2E09.description: The North’s expanding manufacturing economy relied on free labor in contrast to the Southern economy’s dependence on slave labor.  Some Northerners did not object to slavery on principle but claimed that slavery would undermine the free-labor market.  As a result, a free-soil movement arose that portrayed the expansion of slavery as incompatible with free labor.

962168A22FB546488CC5D8093F8F441C.description: Ideological and economic differences over slavery produced an array of diverging responses from Americans in the North and the South.

389BFC7CAE914DA4838466F1EB14922A.description: Intensified by expansion and deepening regional divisions, debates over slavery and other economic, cultural, and political issues led the nation into civil war.

E3074642D62D49A38932CCE8E1BE4342.description: U.S. government interaction and conflict with Mexican Americans and American Indians increased in regions newly taken from American Indians and Mexico, altering these groups’ economic self-sufficiency and cultures.

24476C17D87B48968A2D5C626254ED9B.description: A strongly anti-Catholic nativist movement arose that was aimed at limiting new immigrants’ political power and cultural influence.

5CDE642AF19F4902A5AE27A2E9E0613C.description: Substantial numbers of international migrants continued to arrive in the United States from Europe and Asia, mainly from Ireland and Germany, often settling in ethnic communities where they could preserve elements of their languages and customs.

CFFD9F543B9345488844EBBF80B61AEA.description: In the 1840s and 1850s, Americans continued to debate questions about rights and citizenship for various groups of U.S. in habitants.

36BB046F5633401CB38B70B72EABC3B0.description: U.S. interest in expanding trade led to economic, diplomatic, and cultural initiatives to create more ties with Asia.

5D0C36B2FDF941D6A99B77CD31293E4E.description: Westward migration was boosted during and after the Civil War by the passage of new legislation promoting western transportation and economic development.

8F50CBDDD5834E8F850BDB0EF6883C85.description: The U.S. added large territories in the West through victory in the Mexican-American War and diplomatic negotiations, raising questions about the status of slavery, American Indians, and Mexicans in the newly acquired lands.

3D60389DF43A4484A87FE9DFA43B0D34.description: Advocates of annexing western lands argued that Manifest Destiny and the superiority of American institutions compelled the United States to expands its borders westward to the Pacific Ocean.

9AC385669EAF4039BA9587FA19DCD309.description: The desire for access to natural and mineral resources and the hope of many settlers for economic opportunities or religious refuge led to an increased migration to and settlement in the West.

4C28BC190E224461B8C95559018E4896.description: Popular enthusiasm for U.S. expansion, bolstered by economic and security interests, resulted in the acquisition of new territories, substantial migration westward, and new overseas initiatives.

3415E426CFFA45428065E209DF2A161A.description: The United States became more connected with the world, pursued an expansionist foreign policy in the Western Hemisphere, and emerged as the destination for many migrants from other countries.

0DE895D84E874905ABD5BD34182D6649.description: Congressional attempts at political compromise, such as the Missouri Compromise, only temporarily stemmed growing tensions between opponents and defenders of slavery.

137766B410544BC1808911059EAE55D3.description: Antislavery efforts increased in the North, while in the South, although the majority of Southerners owned no slaves, most leaders argued that slavery was part of the Southern way of life.

8BCF7651BE384D12BB8BBC50C5BB9210.description: As overcultivation depleted arable land in the Southeast, slaveholders began relocating their plantations to more fertile lands west of the Appalachians, where the institution of slavery continued to grow.

3DF552BE54C34BF0B4F9755C4F4F3466.description: The United States’s acquisition of lands in the West gave rise to contests over the extension of slavery into new territories.

0A452ACCD75A4D5D9C5FA80C00BD8709.description: Frontier settlers tended to champion expansion efforts, while American Indian resistance led to a sequence of wars and federal efforts to control and relocate American Indian populations.

EEA45E6B5DD74AA5BAE3E6D2601D3DEC.description: Following the Louisiana Purchase, the United States government sought influence and control over North America and the Western Hemisphere through a variety of means, including exploration, military actions, American Indian removal, and diplomatic efforts such as the Monroe Doctrine.

F64F8E1AC5214CA181F3F9C626438443.description: Struggling to create an independent global presence, the United States sought to claim territory throughout the North American continent and promote foreign trade.

7F035C9880514996AB43A58A880C835B.description: The U.S. interest in increasing foreign trade and expanding its national borders shaped the nation’s foreign policy and spurred government and private initiatives.

29CE9B7B57114893AAD475C9C9496262.description: Plans to further unify the U.S. economy, such as the American System, generated debates over whether such policies would benefit agriculture or industry, potentially favoring different sections of the country.

D6CDB038853A4D79A0DD0DE8EDCD8802.description: Southern business leaders continued to rely on the production and export of traditional agricultural staples, contributing to the growth of a distinctive Southern regional identity.

B58FB4156E504FF98AEA25A42AC3034C.description: Increasing Southern cotton production and the related growth of Northern manufacturing, banking, and shipping industries promoted the development of national and international commercial ties.

A48D93B2E94E410C805D934C656B957A.description: Large numbers of international migrants moved to industrializing northern cities, while many Americans moved west of the Appalachians, developing thriving new communities along the Ohio and Mississippi rivers.

FF5D5DA5A8144A09B9DE3FADCEFE1B17.description: Economic development shaped settlement and trade patterns, helping to unify the nation while also encouraging the growth of different regions.

0A78AEC41B5F43AE8CD81121DEFDFC12.description: Gender and family roles changed in response to the market revolution, particularly with the growth of definitions of domestic ideals that emphasized the separation of public and private spheres.

1A5DBE6E34124D8DBA643A4645215F14.description: The growth of manufacturing drove a significant increase in prosperity and standards of living for some; this led to the emergence of a larger middle class and a small but wealthy business elite but also to a large and growing population of laboring poor.

D782CEE585754BC8A2D7971EBCD39B75.description: Increasing numbers of Americans, especially women and men working in factories, no longer relied semi-subsistence agriculture; instead they supported themselves producing goods for distant markets.

8352A050C3F54BD493936954B080E329.description: The changes caused by the market revolution had significant effects on U.S. society, workers’ lives, and gender and family relations.

FB304EEC0A854921B6E076E6BB823E12.description: Legislation and judicial systems supported the development of roads, canals, and railroads, which extended and enlarged markets and helped foster regional interdependence.  Transportation networks linked the North and Midwest more closely than either was linked to the South.

0D74194B56FA4F7C8B5D40B0AB24D7D6.description: Innovations including textile machinery, steam engines, interchangeable parts, the telegraph, and agricultural inventions increased the efficiency of production methods.

165305A2C5AF47CDBDC345BB0DC7AFA5.description: Entrepreneurs helped to create a market revolution in production and commerce, in which market relationships between producers and consumers came to prevail as the manufacture of goods became more organized.

E0585FCF96564D1C9F75CDFE0F92E58E.description: New transportation systems and technologies dramatically expanded manufacturing and agricultural production.

3AB7F4EA0623465FA446E9591C5E5085.description: Innovations in technology, agriculture, and commerce powerfully accelerated the American economy, precipitating profound changes to U.S. society and to national and regional identities.

4AA463789501494D9D4A00B316F342E9.description: A women’s rights movement sought to create greater equality and opportunities for women, expressing its ideals at the Seneca Falls Convention.

3C526797E1064F7CB10F5398FA4521B9.description: Abolitionist and antislavery movements gradually achieved emancipation in the North, contributing to the growth of the free African American population, even as many state governments restricted African Americans’ rights.  Antislavery efforts in the South were largely limited to unsuccessful slave rebellions.

8E0DE28605854F7BA67B4962304AC9A9.description: Americans formed new voluntary organizations that aimed to change individual behaviors and improve society through temperance and other reform efforts.

2CCC15573F594367AD3DB53482B2C1DF.description: Increasing numbers of Americans, many inspired by new religious and intellectual movements, worked primarily outside of government institutions to advance their ideals

1B7F0E040A0C4E59AC4F591AF06DEBF0.description: Enslaved blacks and free African Americans created communities and strategies to protect their dignity and family structures, and they joined political efforts aimed at changing their status.

69FB029B48D6446DB5E19596273657D5.description: Liberal social ideas from abroad and Romantic beliefs in human perfectibility influenced literature, art, philosophy, and architecture.

B675140A374B4EE39F6E203B170BECDA.description: A new national culture emerged that combined American elements, European influences, and regional cultural sensibilities.

9BC79086566C4C5CBE72E8E8F78D6686.description: The rise of democratic and individualistic beliefs, a response to rationalism, and changes to society caused by the market revolution, along with greater social and geographical mobility, contributed to a Second Great Awakening among Protestants that influenced moral and social reforms and inspired utopian and other religious movements.

6AF50BC94DDA4D1186EA33B49E6A6C23.description: While Americans embraced a new national culture, various groups developed distinctive cultures of their own.

00351F1EE14F436B8FBBB79848B95C33.description: Regional interests often trumped national concerns as the basis for many political leaders’ positions on slavery and economic policy.

E8C5ED4EB07A4C39A85A7A5DF9DCA312.description: By the 1820s and 1830s, new political parties arose—the Democrats, led by Andrew Jackson, and the Whigs, led by Henry Clay—that disagreed about the role and powers of the federal government and issues such as the national bank, tariffs, and federally funded internal improvements.

529C9DEF3DB04FE48920A99ED08495DD.description: Supreme Court decisions established the primacy of the judiciary in determining the meaning of the Constitution and asserted that federal laws took precedence over state laws.

DC2E4CA63AD24071B7E10A1DDC6F2869.description: In the early 1800s, national political parties continued to debate issues such as the tariff, powers of the federal government, and relations with European powers.

4CFB278FCC234FC592AB765D6ADE5194.description: The nation’s transition to a more participatory democracy was achieved by expanding suffrage from a system based on property ownership to one based on voting by all adult white men, and it was accompanied by the growth of political parties.

226908E42DB842688AE75A49A169F462.description: The United States began to develop a modern democracy and celebrated a new national culture, while Americans sought to define the nation’s democratic ideals and change their society and institutions to match them.

089038EC75BD42DE8C8D5A7C8847EBD0.description: George Washington’s Farewell Address encouraged national unity, as he cautioned against political factions and warned about the danger of permanent foreign alliances.

FF6E7C7EC3624E01B05DBA72628936E5.description: War between France and Britain resulting from the French Revolution presented challenges to the United States over issues of free trade and foreign policy and fostered political disagreement.

9994CAEFB15C428B987F4B46EACCC266.description: The United States government forged diplomatic initiatives aimed at dealing with the continued British and Spanish presence in North America, as U.S. settlers migrated beyond the Appalachians and sought free navigation of the Mississippi River.

201D5C41B1C4472ABE2B4298DB0BE8BA.description: The continued presence of European powers in North America challenged the United States to find ways to safeguard its borders, maintain neutral trading rights, and promote its economic interests.

F95B0AAA18E64EC1AB81470BF0622AF4.description: The Spanish, supported by the bonded labor of the local American Indians, expanded their mission settlements into California; these provided opportunities for social mobility among soldiers and led to new cultural blending.

631BF30369BC4DE2A566ED65D72E6431.description: An ambiguous relationship between the federal government and American Indian tribes contributed to problems regarding treaties and American Indian legal claims relating to the seizure of their lands.

3F0B6B52A1264A8FAF86097143DDEB23.description: As settlers moved westward during the 1780s, Congress enacted the Northwest Ordinance for admitting new states; the ordinance promoted public education, the protection of private property, and a ban on slavery in the Northwest Territory.

FE164A46592C4681A2C3763FBCBF5B82.description: As increasing numbers of migrants from North America and other parts of the world continued to move westward, frontier cultures that had emerged in the colonial period continued to grow, fueling social, political, and ethnic tensions.

919FE733DDE540EBA572C26FA130AC05.description: Various American Indian groups repeatedly evaluated and adjusted their alliances with Europeans, other tribes, and the U.S., seeking to limit migration of white settlers and maintain control of tribal lands and natural resources.  British alliances with American Indians contributed to tensions between the U.S. and Britain.

AB15B1C1F6974CDDB2F84B2B153022CA.description: In the decades after American independence, interactions among different groups resulted in competition for resources, shifting alliances, and cultural blending.

2241836AD9B44C60972890211970BA3F.description: Migration within North America and competition over resources, boundaries, and trade intensified conflicts among peoples and nations.

D272B1C149FF4FB8BFA04CC735D8A5E8.description: Ideas about national identity increasingly found expression in works of art, literature, and architecture.

30C7E6A5A54247D3A4234DF1E14453F8.description: The expansion of slavery in the deep South and adjacent western lands and rising antislavery sentiment began to create distinctive regional attitudes toward the institution.

3218E8C375C64D968C2CE924191EF325.description: The Political leaders in the 1790s took a variety of positions on issues such as the relationship between the national government and the states, economic policy, foreign policy, and the balance between liberty and order.  This led to the formation of political parties – most significantly the Federalists, led by Alexander Hamilton, and the Democratic-Republican Party, led by Thomas Jefferson and James Madison.

D082C048D1AF4B0280B086A40F69A979.description: During the presidential administrations of George Washington and John Adams, political leaders created institutions and precedents that put the principles of the Constitution into practice.

BB25B0399F9A4A72ACBFC17267B7AA44.description: New forms of national culture and political institutions developed in the United States alongside continued regional variations and differences over economic, political, social, and foreign policy issues.

5849EE22D0994CC1B7E80645A5172549.description: In the debate over ratifying the Constitution, Anti-Federalists opposing ratification battled with Federalists, whose principles were articulated in the Federalist Papers (primarily written by Alexander Hamilton and James Madison).  Federalists ensured the ratification of the Constitution by promising the addition of a Bill of Rights that enumerated individual rights and explicitly restricted the powers of the federal government.

AC364100BEA846B3A34ED85E7A1D02E6.description: The Constitutional Convention compromised over the representation of slave states in Congress and the role of the federal government in regulating both slavery and the slave trade, allowing the prohibition of the international slave trade after 1808.

01947B5CE91E4BA8A074D3DD371608C5.description: Delegates from the states participated in a Constitutional Convention and through negotiation, collaboration, and compromise proposed a constitution that created a limited but dynamic central government embodying federalism and providing for a separation of powers between its three branches.

A25674EE73CA4E81ADAB555939714219.description: The Articles of Confederation unified the newly independent states, creating a central government with limited power.  After the Revolution, difficulties over international trade, finances, interstate commerce, foreign relations, and internal unrest led to calls for a stronger central government.

E8333FCFA0194FCABF3A7EA9C663CB0F.description: Many new state constitutions placed power in the hands of the legislative branch and maintained property qualifications for voting and citizenship.

4150DEF1012843F389BA1B3166F75C6B.description: After declaring independence, American political leaders created new constitutions and declaration of rights that articulated the role of state and federal governments while protecting individual liberties and limiting both centralized power and excessive popular influence.

674B986553FF49B38BAE489C28BBFB42.description: The American Revolution and the ideals set forth in the Declaration of Independence reverberated in France, Haiti, and Latin America, inspiring future independence movements.

6E6985CD1AD44551A2DDEE286925A3C7.description: In response to women’s participation in the American Revolution, Enlightenment ideas, and women’s appeals for expanded roles, an ideal of “republican motherhood” gained popularity.  It called on women to teach republican values within the family and granted women a new importance in American political culture.

B5807097E2E8442280A6B50665346295.description: During and after the American Revolution, an increased awareness of inequalities in society motivated some individuals and groups to call for the abolition of slavery and greater political democracy in the new state and national governments.

3B1D4F6B328A4A3E8A950043A4178B8C.description: The colonists’ belief in the superiority of republican forms of government based on the natural rights of the people found expression in Thomas Paine’s Common Sense and the Declaration of Independence.  The ideas in these documents resonated throughout American history, shaping Americans’ understanding of the ideals on which the nation was based.

1C73E0E734D246AA87668092435718A2.description: Enlightenment ideas and philosophy inspired many American political thinkers to emphasize individual talent over hereditary privilege, while religion strengthened Americans’ view of themselves as a people blessed with liberty.

DF38AD5135D740F5A2ADDF3A998E0513.description: The ideals that inspired the revolutionary cause reflected new beliefs about politics, religion, and society that had been developing over the course of the 18th century.

FC5BEB765EC14CF29D39E5B1B1EE9301.description: The American Revolution’s democratic and republican ideals inspired new experiments with different forms of government.

FDCDD075F2364A59A1C319D6C4C71C2B.description: Despite considerable loyalist opposition, as well as Great Britain’s apparently overwhelming military and financial advantages, the Patriot cause succeeded because of the actions of colonial militias and the Continental Army, George Washington’s military leadership, the colonists’ ideological commitment and resilience, and assistance sent by European allies.

8489481F27794E1D8301F133506E368F.description: In the face of economic shortages and the British military occupation of some regions, men and women mobilized in large numbers to provide financial and material support to the Patriot movement.

F3686F2328174A399AB9C6152FD85E9C.description: The effort for American independence was energized by colonial leaders such as Benjamin Franklin, as well as by popular movements that included the political activism of laborers, artisans, and women.

F5F401298667443195A1821D6948209E.description: Colonial leaders based their calls for resistance to Britain on arguments about the rights of British subjects, the rights of the individual, local traditions of self-rule, and the ideas of the Enlightenment.

E07F2FC680EE42E7A5AC6A5BA00EC799.description: The imperial struggles of the mid-18th century, as well as new British efforts to collect taxes without direct colonial representation or consent and to assert imperial authority in the colonies, began to unite the colonists against perceived and real constraints on their economic activities and political rights.

BB908CFFBACD4338A8F7BEFDEE199F9E.description: The desire of many colonists to assert ideals of self-government in the face of renewed British imperial efforts led to a colonial independence movement and war with Britain.

F320A5A259E4430096537030A8C1A8EE.description: After the British victory, imperial officials’ attempts to prevent colonists from moving westward generated colonial opposition, while native groups sought to both continue trading with Europeans and resist the encroachments of colonists on tribal lands.

59F6EBA85AFA44BE8968F5C28E04ED67.description: Britain achieved a major expansion of its territorial holdings by defeating the French, but at tremendous expense, setting the stage for imperial efforts to raise revenue and consolidate control over the colonies.

8477531DBD114C4BAE3D77CF31265A2A.description: Colonial rivalry intensified between Britain and France in the mid-18th century, as the growing population of the British colonies expanded into the interior of North America, threatening French—Indian trade networks and American Indian autonomy.

A022DC13B99D4BA59AA184ED3FE83705.description: The competitions among the British, French, and American Indians for economic and political advantage in North America culminated in the Seven Years’ War (the French and Indian War), in which Britain defeated France and allied American Indians.

E8C2AE90B7CC456F891E6C7A21455070.description: British attempts to assert tighter control over its North American colonies and the colonial resolve to pursue self-government led to a colonial independence movement and the Revolutionary War.

CBF5CB4A22CC4592828E2A031C5F9618.description: Africans developed both overt and covert means to resist the dehumanizing aspects of slavery and maintain their family and gender systems, culture, and religion.

59E3C90EF99146F6ABE51525A0B1D567.description: As chattel slavery became the dominant labor system in many southern colonies, new laws created a strict racial system that prohibited interracial relationships and defined the descendants of African American mothers as black and enslaved in perpetuity.

221163DE27A1485A93969289676C3673.description: All the British colonies participated to varying degrees in the Atlantic slave trade due to the abundance of land and a growing European demand for colonial goods, as well as a shortage of indentured servants.  Small New England farms used relatively few enslaved laborers, all port cities held significant minorities of enslaved people, and the emerging plantation systems of the Chesapeake and the southern Atlantic coast had large numbers of enslaved workers, while the great majority of enslaved Africans were sent to the West Indies.

EEEA6DCF715342338BF9C70768AD02F2.description: Like other European empires in the Americas that participated in the Atlantic slave trade, the English colonies developed a system of slavery that reflected the specific economic, demographic, and geographic characteristics of those colonies.

FABF0FFD34F44651B6BE214F7E4B0A2B.description: Colonists’ resistance to imperial control drew on local experiences of self-government, evolving ideas of liberty, the political thought of the Enlightenment, greater religious independence and diversity, and an ideology critical of perceived corruption in the imperial system.

4CD5E3F1F989457495B90CF22E454073.description: The British government increasingly attempted to incorporate its North American colonies into a coherent, hierarchical, and imperial structure in order to pursue mercantilist economic aims, but conflicts with colonists and American Indians led to erratic enforcement of imperial policies.

08576D3ED04C4A5BBCDE08D6AD461B85.description: The British colonies experienced a gradual Anglicization over time, developing autonomous political communities based on English models with influence from intercolonial commercial ties, the emergence of a trans-Atlantic print culture, and the spread of Protestant evangelicalism.

3C43E87598CF4856A15A7872E24158E4.description: The presence of different European religious and ethnic groups contributed to a significant degree of pluralism and intellectual exchange, which were later enhanced by the first Great Awakening and the spread of European Enlightenment ideas.

2860B14859DD4D358644DF98CD6B019C.description: Transatlantic commercial, religious, philosophical, and political exchanges led residents of the British colonies to evolve in their political and cultural attitudes as they became increasingly tied to Britain and one another.

5A2497B973C74C34BBA2D1B5D64E7C06.description: The British colonies participated in political, social, cultural, and economic exchanges with Great Britain that encouraged both stronger bonds with Britain and resistance to Britain’s control.

48A64EAFC58B47829FE686DEA774E4ED.description: American Indian resistance to Spanish colonizing efforts in North America, particularly after the Pueblo Revolt, led to Spanish accommodation of some aspects of American Indian culture in the Southwest.

2C34CD84855144AEBB16333D7CC8A4E0.description: British conflicts with American Indians over land, resources, and political boundaries led to military confrontations, such as Metacom’s War (King Philip’s War) in New England.

A72BEAEBF32C4910B6A75AFEB62320EC.description: The goals and interest of European leaders and colonists at times diverged, leading to a growing mistrust on both sides of the Atlantic.  Colonists, especially in British North America, expressed dissatisfaction over issues including territorial settlements, frontier defense, self-rule, and trade.

12A76EC5F4B7482AAE8D8A8266D7336A.description: Interactions between European rivals and American Indian populations fostered both accommodation and conflict.  French, Dutch, British, and Spanish colonies allied with and armed American Indian groups, who frequently sought alliances with Europeans against other American Indian groups.

FB20233507CC41B0BDA87D47D6AAEED5.description: Continuing trade with Europeans increased the flow of goods in and out of American Indian communities, stimulating cultural and economic changes and spreading epidemic diseases that caused radical demographic shifts.

3C66CA920DBA484E93E8D6D0AE04D3F0.description: An Atlantic economy developed in which goods, as well as enslaved Africans and American Indians, were exchanged between Europe, Africa, and the Americas through extensive trade networks.  European colonial economies focused on acquiring, producing, and exporting commodities that were valued in Europe and gaining new sources of labor.

17180D7575F54503AD60613EB218A962.description: Competition over resources between European rivals and American Indians encouraged industry and trade and led to conflict in the Americas.

B2997BD9CB7D41DF987E2AFB2104EB83.description: Distance and Britain’s initially lax attention led to the colonies creating self-governing institutions that were unusually democratic for the era.  The New England colonies based power in participatory town meetings, which in turn elected members to their colonial legislatures; in the southern colonies, elite planters exercised local authority and also dominated the elected assemblies.

7C9E918207D8449588A23BB214B193B0.description: The colonies of the southern Atlantic coast and the British West Indies used long growing seasons to develop plantation economies based on exporting staple crops.  They depended on the labor of enslaved Africans, who often constituted the majority of the population in these areas and developed their own forms of cultural and religious autonomy.

8D65B60D5BA241C39396845578875C9C.description: The middle colonies supported a flourishing export economy based on cereal crops and attracted a broad range of European migrants, leading to societies with greater cultural, ethnic, and religious diversity and tolerance.

BF5BA797B0C94BD9A20BD30577A0A115.description: The New England colonies, initially settled by Puritans, developed around small towns with family farms and achieved a thriving mixed economy of agriculture and commerce.

21780AD5038D4995AF32F741FA905D09.description: The Chesapeake and North Carolina colonies grew prosperous exporting tobacco—a labor-intensive product initially cultivated by white, mostly male indentured servants and later by enslaved Africans.

8B4D323B25E74A429A2D4B304E7BEB3C.description: In the 17th century, early British colonies developed along the Atlantic coast, with regional differences that reflected various environmental, economic, cultural, and demographic factors.

D2033B022D6D4BA2B2E467C1C066BA5D.description: English colonization efforts attracted a comparatively large number of male and female British migrants, all of whom sought social mobility, economic prosperity, religious freedom, and improved living conditions.  These colonists focused on agriculture and settled on land taken from Native Americans, from whom they lived separately.

B889A2E002054A6BBAB55E9FF583BFD9.description: French and Dutch colonial efforts involved relatively few Europeans and relied on trade alliances and intermarriage with American Indians to build economic and diplomatic relationships and acquire furs and other products for export to Europe.

B888D101CDDF476E9DE05BEEADE0A3E8.description: Spanish efforts to extract wealth from the land led them to develop institutions based on subjugating native populations, converting them to Christianity, and incorporating them, along with enslaved and free Africans, into the Spanish colonial society.

B53434AC52984C5FB6EC5C6A86818685.description: Spanish, French, Dutch, and British colonizers had different economic and imperial goals involving land and labor that shaped the social and political development of their colonies as well as their relationships with native populations.

E159EBF0DF4247B3A9B965F999369F41.description: Europeans developed a variety of colonization and migration patterns, influenced by different imperial goals, cultures, and the varied North American environments where they settled, and they competed with each other and American Indians for resources.

AB94D7DFAA2C4E61A5E0576E13CC8BC1.description: Extended contact with Native Americans and Africans fostered debate among European religious and political leaders about how non-Europeans should be treated, as well as evolving religious, cultural, and racial justifications for the subjugation of Africans and Native Americans.

DAB7E40819FF4752875416BC08DABF7F.description: As European encroachments on Native Americans’ lands and demands on their labor increased, native peoples sought to defend and maintain their political sovereignty, economic prosperity, religious beliefs, and concepts of gender relations through diplomatic negotiations and military resistance.

6C046B78850B4DE4A5034A585D3DAEFD.description: Mutual misunderstandings between Europeans and Native Americans often defined the early years of interaction and trade as each group sought to make sense of the other.  Over time, Europeans and Native Americans adopted some useful aspects of each other’s culture.

25770CA877224BADA0759007DA436769.description: In their interactions, Europeans and Native Americans asserted divergent worldviews regarding issues such as religion, gender roles, family, land use, and power.

851A440092EE45179CE6B62ED4F571AB.description: The Spanish developed a caste system that incorporated, and carefully defined the status of, the diverse population of Europeans, Africans, and Native Americans in their empire.

BDD88FAAAAE448FBBC07C14BB84D1E3E.description: European traders partnered with some West African groups who practiced slavery to forcibly extract slave labor for the Americas.  The Spanish imported enslaved Africans to labor in plantation agriculture and mining.

85BDB48CECBA4BB8B8999DF3A27F9A48.description: In the encomienda system, Spanish colonial economies marshaled Native American labor to support plantation-based agriculture and extract precious metals and other resources.

9992D5E983DD44C284F84724186DF3F1.description: Spanish exploration and conquest of the Americas were accompanied and furthered by widespread deadly epidemics that devastated native populations and by the introduction of crops and animals not found in the Americas.

B6E9241D99A14B769B179F3E43B0163E.description: The Columbian Exchange and development of the Spanish Empire in the Western Hemisphere resulted in extensive demographic, economic, and social changes.

B0CE924DE02B44B5A9B340D9CD8445E2.description: Improvements in maritime technology and more organized methods for conducting international trade, such as joint-stock companies, helped drive changes to economies in Europe and North America.

42A8A47EE6FA41E5AFC38F99D1A3DEC6.description: The Columbian Exchange brought new crops to Europe from the Americas, stimulating European population growth, and new sources of mineral wealth, which facilitated the European shift from feudalism to capitalism.

BA9AB3A4A0454E749FCB30E585942852.description: European nations’ efforts to explore and conquer the New World stemmed from a search for new sources of wealth, economic and military competition, and a desire to spread Christianity.

49E27055BE4A45CBB6515ECBE2E3A0E0.description: European expansion into the Western Hemisphere generated intense social, religious, political, and economic competition and changes within European societies.

9C272728DA3B4A96BFA119F549BEA3B1.description: Contact among Europeans, Native Americans, and Africans resulted in the Columbian Exchange and significant social, cultural, and political changes on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.

1CBFAF030B43490DB6C0CE78BB74ADAD.description: Societies in the Northwest and present-day California supported themselves by hunting and gathering, and in some areas developed settled communities supported by the vast resources of the ocean.

327FAA61847D4434AC094AE626DCAE0D.description: In the Northeast, the Mississippi River Valley, and along the Atlantic Seaboard some societies developed mixed agricultural and hunter-gatherer economies that favored the development of permanent villages.

762A0EDA370741E08D8111D96C9AB1BB.description: Societies responded to the aridity of the Great Basin and the grasslands of the western Great Plains by developing largely mobile lifestyles.

D8F9CC51E52E486786C015940B46A84D.description: The spread of maize cultivation from present-day Mexico northward into the present-day American Southwest and beyond supported development, settlement, advanced irrigation, and social diversification among societies.

4EA5A099185342048741289F2A8AA44F.description: Different native societies adapted to and transformed their environments through innovations in agriculture, resources use, and social structure.

2BA744E39EFB4875B8B71B05F2D2CDD4.description: As native populations migrated and settled across the vast expanse of North America over time, they developed distinct and increasingly complex societies by adapting to and transforming their diverse environments.
